name: Charleston
fun_fact: Fun fact: Charleston just received its first-ever Michelin stars in 2025 - three restaurants earned one star each, making it the newest American city to join the prestigious Michelin Guide, with all recognized spots showcasing authentic Lowcountry flavors.

hero_dishes.name: Shrimp and Grits
hero_dishes.description: Creamy stone-ground grits topped with fresh local shrimp, usually in a rich sauce with bacon, onions, and peppers
hero_dishes.origin_story: This Lowcountry classic evolved from a simple breakfast fishermen ate before heading out on the water. Charleston chefs elevated it to fine dining status in the 1980s, and it's now the city's signature dish
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Swamp Fox at Francis Marion Hotel (award-winning version), Hank's Seafood, Slightly North of Broad (S.N.O.B.)

hero_dishes.name: She-Crab Soup
hero_dishes.description: Rich, creamy soup made with blue crab meat and roe, flavored with sherry and topped with a delicate crab foam
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in Charleston in the early 1900s when a butler to Mayor Goodwyn Rhett added crab roe to basic crab soup to make it more elegant for a presidential visit. The roe gives it a distinctive orange color
hero_dishes.where_to_find: The Swamp Fox (remarkable version), Hank's Seafood, Poogan's Porch

hero_dishes.name: Lowcountry Boil
hero_dishes.description: A communal feast of shrimp, corn, potatoes, and smoked sausage boiled together with Old Bay seasoning, then dumped on newspaper-covered tables
hero_dishes.origin_story: Also called Frogmore Stew, this one-pot meal originated in nearby Beaufort and represents the Lowcountry's tradition of casual, communal dining where everyone gathers around the table
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Leon's Fine Poultry and Oysters, local backyard cookouts, The Darling

hero_dishes.name: Carolina Gold Rice Dishes
hero_dishes.description: Heritage rice dishes showcasing Carolina Gold rice - a variety that built Charleston's plantation economy and is now making a culinary comeback
hero_dishes.origin_story: Carolina Gold rice made Charleston one of the wealthiest cities in colonial America. Chef Jason Stanhope at Lowland and other chefs are reviving this heritage grain in modern Lowcountry cooking
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lowland (Chef Jason Stanhope), Middleton Place Restaurant (grown on-site)

signature_drinks.name: Sweet Tea
signature_drinks.description: Heavily sweetened black tea served ice-cold - it's practically sacred in the South
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Locals drink gallons of it, especially in summer. It's on every table, at every meal, and the debate over the proper sugar-to-tea ratio is taken very seriously

signature_drinks.name: Charleston Light Dragoon Punch
signature_drinks.description: A historic cocktail made with rum, brandy, champagne, and tea - served at fancy receptions
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: This 18th-century punch was the drink of Charleston's elite military society. It's still served at elegant Charleston events and high-end restaurants

food_culture_notes: Lowcountry cuisine blends West African, French, English, and Native American influences
Farm-to-table is a way of life - chefs have close relationships with local farmers and fishermen
The 2025 Michelin Guide recognition included 3 one-star restaurants and 3 Bib Gourmand awards
Charleston has won more James Beard Awards than any other Southern city its size
